metadata.title: Master The Basics Of Git & GitHub | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Master The Basics Of Git & GitHub
metadata.description: Everything you need to know to get started using Git & GitHub

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: Find the GitHub repository used in this article here
To learn more advanced Git & GitHub concepts you can read my second Git & GitHub article here

all_paragraphs: Prod is down! What is it this time? The test cases we wrote covered all the use cases we could imagine — and they all passed after we updated our services yesterday. If only we could go back and investigate all the recent changes to our code to see what went wrong! This is the type of problem Git exists to solve.
In this article, I’m going to show you how to use Git to track the history of files in your project so that you will be able to diagnose bugs whenever they appear in your project.

GitHub is web application that allows users to host files kind of like DropBox or Google Drive — but it is designed to host Git Repositories. Git is a command-line tool used primarily by programmers to manage the versioning (history) of software projects. Each project lives inside a Git Repository that retains the history of all changes.

Following the below link you can install Git by clicking on whichever operating system you are using at the top of the page. After you install Git, go to your command prompt if you are on Windows or your terminal if you are on MacOS or Linux. Type “git” and hit enter. If you see any information about Git, you installed it correctly! If you get “command not found” — try uninstalling and reinstalling git, or reconfiguring your environment variables.
The below link will take you to GitHub. From there you can set up an account using your email address.

On any page on GitHub while you are logged in you will see a white plus sign next to your profile image in the toolbar on the top right. Clicking the plus sign will reveal a drop down menu where you should select: “New repository”. From there, you should name the repository something like “Master_Git_And_GitHub_Basics_Article” — taking into account they do not allow you to use spaces in the name. You don’t need to add a description and you can leave the default “Public” access enabled. For this lesson you should not check the “Initialize with Readme file” checkbox, and lastly you don’t need to add a .gitignore file or a license — so you can click the bottom “Create repository” button.

The following page will have a lot of tiny intimidating text. The only information you will need to worry about on this page is the blue shaded box on the top that is labeled “Quick setup”. Inside the blue “Quick setup” box make sure “HTTPS” is selected and and not “SSH”. On the far left of the menu there is a clipboard icon button you can select to copy the URL address you need to clone your repository to your computer.

In your terminal or git bash, go to the directory you would like to put your repository in using the “cd directory_name” command. Then run the following command (Replace my URL with the URL you copied from GitHub):

Running that command should create an empty folder in the directory you ran the command from. You can think of cloning a repository like downloading it— but more. It also downloads the history of all the changes made to those files. Let’s run the command “cd Master_Git_And_GitHub_Basics_Article” in our command prompt or terminal to go into our new repository we just cloned. Now that we’re in the repository, we can get the status of our repository using the command:
The git status command will show us all the changes we’ve made to our repository since our last commit. For us it will say:

NOTE: If your Git Bash/Terminal/Command Prompt does not display the same color scheme and the green “(main #)” message — don’t worry. I have my Git Bash profile configured to give me those extra colors and messages.

All this is telling us is that we don’t have any history yet because we don’t have any commits. You may wonder what “On branch main” means — but we will address that in the next article. Now we’ll add some history.

In a Git Repository we record history in commits. As we have seen in our git status output, we currently have no commits. In order to create a commit we need to make some changes in our repository. Make a new file in either your file explorer or your finder window and drag it into your repository directory. My file will just be “file.txt” with no content. Now if I go back to my command prompt or terminal and run “git status” — I will see my new file:

Now you can see how useful git status is in showing us our changes. You’ll notice that the file.txt file is listed in untracked files. Remember that Git wants to track all of the changes that happen in the repository — but we have to tell it which files to track. To make this apparent — let’s add a second file called file2.txt so we can see what happens when we track one file but not the other. After adding a second file to the repository and verifying that it appears as untracked when you run “git status” we’ll learn our next Git command:
We select files to be tracked using “git add <FILE_NAME>”. Notice we have only selected the first file. Now when we run git status we get the output:

Notice that file.txt is listed under a new header: ”Changes to be committed” and that file2.txt is still listed under “Untracked”. Keep in mind we have not tracked anything by adding the file — we have just selected the file to be tracked when we commit. Now that we have selected the changes we want to add to our commit, we can create our first commit in our project using:

This command will create our commit with the message: “adding file.txt”. Every commit must have a message describing what changed so that it will be easy to navigate our history in the future. Let’s take a look at the output of our commit command:

This tells us that we added a new commit that is the “root-commit” since it is the first one. Future commits will not be “root commits”. Our commit has the message “added file.txt”, and it only includes one file change where we created the “file.txt”. Lastly, we’ll learn one more command that will list all of the commits in our repository in descending order:
Only one commit is listed since we only have one and it also tells us the author, the date, and the message for each commit.
Once you have committed your changes — no one will be able to see them on your GitHub profile until you push your code with the command:
Now your changes have been uploaded to your GitHub for everyone to see. Go check it out!

Notice, file2.txt is not there since we did not select it to be committed. We can click “1 commit” on the far left of the toolbar in the middle of of the screen to see all of our commits kind of like how git log shows us.

Now you know how to use the git commands: clone, status, add, commit, log, and push. You can now keep updating your repository with new changes. git add the files that you change to select them to be committed. Then commit them with a message describing what you did and push them to GitHub for others to see. Stay tuned for the next tutorial where we’ll learn all about using git branches to collaborate with other developers on our software projects.

Thanks for reading! I’d love to hear your feedback or take any questions about my articles, so please comment below.
